title: Thursday, 5th April, 2018

Which is a fair summary of the past 24 hours. We were all worried about trade wars and then we weren't and essentially nothing has happened between those two points.

An email search for "phony trade war" turns up at least a dozen hits for today, and none whatsoever for yesterday.

BE11:09am

One of which is DB's Reid.

11:09 am
BE11:10am

We’re at an important point in the phoney trade war that’s currently playing out
between the US and China. As the European session opened China retaliated to
the prior day US move by proposing 25% tariffs on around $50bn of US imports
(therefore an equal reaction in $ terms). The levies are reciprocal but won’t come
in immediately, but only after the US tariffs officially come into force and depends
on the outcome of bilateral negotiations, so still time for things to de-escalate but
it was a rapid response.
As our Chinese economist Zhiwei Zhang put it yesterday “The US
announcement of tariff against China is well expected, but the Chinese reaction
is stronger and faster than we expected. The macro impact on China's growth is
negligible at this stage, but another step further by either side would likely trigger
retaliation with visible macro impact”.
Zhiwei thinks there is room for the two sides to negotiate though. His baseline
is for the lists on both sides to be shortened. The tension will likely continue with
tough talk from both sides, but he does not see further escalation beyond the lists
announced yesterday. Zhiwei believes China is still willing to make compromise
and open the service sector in exchange for a resolution of the trade tension.
It remains in the best interest for both sides to eventually negotiate, though
timing wise it may go beyond 2018. See his note here for more details about his
views and what China have announced. Elsewhere, our US economists have also
outlined the key products as proposed by the USTR and time line for negotiations
in their note yesterday.
For us, the dilemma for markets is that equities are now ‘cheap’ relative
to current economic activity (see yesterday’s equities vs PMI analysis) and
therefore if you think the trade war fears are overblown and the economy
stabilises then this is a good short term buying opportunity. However if the war
escalates then sentiment will undoubtedly worsen further. Indeed it feels that
equities are unlikely to settle at these levels. They’re more likely to rebound sharply
with easing tensions or slump more with any further escalations. The status quo
and low vol is the least likely outcome.

Which means there's nearly nothing to say about the trading update, which is reassuring generally but mostly just emphasises how far apart buyside and sellside expectations had shifted.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

Here's Credit Suisse ....

BE11:17am

Sophos has today published a trading update ahead
of FY18 results in May, outlining that the group anticipates reported billings
growth of approximately 23% (16% in constant currency) for 4Q18, and that
FY billings growth is expected to land at the top end of the 20-22% guidance
range. In light of recent newsflow, we think this reacceleration of billings
growth will have a positive and material impact on the share price. We make
no forecast changes today, and continue to feel that at on a Mar FY20E FCF
yield of 7% (with the share price at 480p), Sophos remains an attractive
investment opportunity. We therefore reiterate our Outperform rating.

BE11:18am

We continue to feel that Sophos is wellpositioned
in a strong and growing security end market, and were
encouraged to see the company once again be recognised as a leader in the
Gartner Magic Quadrant for Endpoint Protection. A recent update to the
InterceptX platform is further helping the company to capitalize upon trends
such as crypto-currency-fuelled ransomware and incrementally increase
market share. This leaves the company well positioned as we move into
FY19.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

And Citi.

BE11:18am

We reiterate our Buy rating. Sophos’ share price has declined 27%
YTD on the back of negative sentiment regarding slowing growth trends. We expect
the in-line trading update to provide the market with some reassurance regarding
near term trends and support share price sentiment. Management view results to be
on track to deliver their target for $1 billion of billings by FY20e.

Although Sophos will face another tough base comparison in 2Q19, we are
comfortable with our FY19 numbers and we view today's update as
demonstrating that underlying momentum in the business remains. This should see the group on track to return to c. 15% billings growth in 2H19 and FY20, reaching management guidance for c. $1bn of billings by 2020. With Sophos
shares having fallen c. 28% YTD, underperforming the wider tech space, and trading at c. 4.2x CY19e EV/recurring we continue to view the risk / reward as
attractive.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

JUST EAT has been one of our top picks in the Internet sector and the
wider Media space for the last three years (and has been a stellar performer
throughout). From here, we turn more cautious. Rather than the well-discussed
increase in investment levels due to delivery, we see a much bigger issue for
the UK operations going forward. As a result of the delayed move into
delivery, JUST EAT’s core customer base (in terms of restaurants) is still very
much skewed towards the lower-price segment which increasingly brings
strategic disadvantages: 1) The high/mid-price segment demands delivery and
is already taken by first movers Deliveroo/UberEATS, which are strongly
gaining share outside London; and 2) in the low-price segment, chains are
rapidly expanding into rural areas and cannibalizing JUST EAT’s marketplace
business. Given these developments, the UK is less stable than previously
anticipated, and we now value the UK at £2.4bn (8% FCF yield) vs. £4.0bn
before. Our Dec-18 PT falls to 656p from 976p and we d/g to UW from OW.

Flaneur Touché.

.... but what he did say was that Takeda is interested in buying the whole company, it's strategically important for the current plan though not essential, and he'll stretch the balance sheet in the short term to get it done.

BE11:32am

.... without risking junk or the divi, so I guess that'd mean a load of equity. But we already knew that.

BE11:33am

The upshot is that Takeda's once again being seen as a credible bidder. Cynicism had been on the rise recently, due to its size mostly.

Miss Piggy NFP jobs tomorrow.
11:34 am
BE11:34am

Credit Suisse breaks it into bullet points.

BE11:35am

1. Takeda will be disciplined in its approach to the Shire acquisition (in
finances, purchase price, etc.).
2. This possible acquisition is just one option being considered to achieve the
Vision 2025 strategy and does not represent a change in strategy. Takeda
has sensed some confidence in the progress it has made thus far toward
achieving the Vision 2025 strategy.
3. Acquisition of Shire would allow Takeda to achieve the Vision 2025 strategy
sooner. The two companies are a good fit in sales by field and country or
region. For example, 30% of Takeda’s pipeline drugs are for rare diseases,
so there are good synergies.
4. Takeda is exploring the acquisition of the entire company (Shire plc) and is
not considering purchasing only some businesses or assets.
5. Takeda is not exploring this possibility simply for tax savings through a tax
inversion or head office relocation. The goal would only be to become a
global pharma business that is based in Japan.
6. Takeda is looking to maintain its current credit rating (e.g., Moody’s Japan
A1). No change will be made in the dividend policy (¥180 DPS).
7. In financial discipline, Takeda indicated that even if the net debt/EBITDA
multiple rose above 3x over the near term (currently at approx. 1.8x for
Takeda), Takeda would work to quickly bring this down to around 2x.
8. Takeda will make an announcement in accordance with the UK’s Panel on
Takeovers and Mergers regulations by 5:00 p.m. on 25 April (UK time) and
will announce by the same date whether it will submit an offer for Shire.

Here's Chris Bosworth, Director of Strategy at Close Brothers Motor Finance:

VV75 Leaf was most popular car in Norway in march
BE11:49am

Today’s figures come as a disappointment. Traditionally March is a popular month to buy vehicles as the new number plates are out, and this month’s figures should have been boosted by a spike in demand before the new VED changes set in. That said, petrol and alternative fuels remain the heroes of the forecourts, with diesel suffering and seeing yet another month of decline.

As we begin the one year countdown to Brexit we expect turbulence in the sector to continue, but dealers are not powerless to adapt. They need to be willing and able to offer the most appropriate finance and stock to their customers, whether that’s diesel, petrol, or electric. The strong pound should ease the way and allow them to buy better value stock, while also offering breathing space for the losses incurred by cars sat on the forecourt.

RBC says:

12:05 pm
BE12:05pm

BTG has issued its FY18 trading update, which we see as mixed overall in spite of commentary for an ‘in-line’ performance at the top line. Whilst established IM assets (Ekosonic and IO assets) have delivered mid-teens CER growth, we note the performance from early-stage asset PneumRx Coil is weak (and still too soon to turn positive on Varithena). With Licensing and Pharma products still helping to maintain growth rates (both mid-single-digit growth at CER), we see medium-term risks to both. Overall, whilst we see quality in BTG and specifically its IO and Ekosonic assets that support long-term growth, plus a strong balance sheet to support acquisitions, we think the disappointing sales growth from earlier-stage IM assets and risks to established brands could see revenue and profit growth stall. Given the current market environment for share prices to react negatively to mixed results (especially when highly valued), we see risks and prefer to wait on the sidelines, for now.

BE12:06pm

And Shore.

BE12:06pm

Valuation does not depend on early-stage IM assets: as we noted in our initiation we are very cautious on the prospects for BTG’s early-stage IM portfolio (Varithena and PneumRx) as we believe questions remain around clinical and cost-effectiveness for both assets. Our model contains combined sales of only £70m for both products by 2022F. In addition, we have been more cautious on growth rates in the interventional oncology and vascular portfolio in the outer years with our forecasts assuming a 2023-2030F revenue CAGR of 7-8%, despite the mid to high teens CER performance to date and the large, underpenetrated IM markets.

As such although we would anticipate some weakness in the shares today, prior to any changes to our model, our current target price of 780p suggests c.20% upside and is based upon conservative estimates for both early-stage IM assets (Varithena and PenrumRx) and overall profitability.
